summary: This is a transcript of a court proceeding, likely a pre-trial hearing or motion hearing in the case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The judge rules on government motions regarding the use of the term 'victim' and the use of pseudonyms for witnesses and alleged victims, citing legal precedents and the Crime Victims' Rights Act. The judge grants the government's request to use pseudonyms to protect witnesses from harassment and embarrassment.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Referred to as the defendant in the case; the defense counsel is arguing on her behalf regarding the use of terms like 'victim' and pseudonyms for witnesses.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in passing as the individual with whom the alleged victims' public statements may be related.

persons.name: Judge Furman
persons.context: Cited by the presiding judge for a decision in the United States v. Dupigny case regarding the use of the term 'victim' and jury instructions.

persons.name: Dupigny
persons.context: Defendant in a cited case (United States v. Dupigny) referenced by the judge regarding legal procedures for using the term 'victim'.

persons.name: Washburn
persons.context: Defendant in a cited appellate case (United States v. Washburn) referenced regarding the government's burden of proof.

persons.name: Server
persons.context: Party in a cited appellate case (Server v. Mizell) referenced regarding legal standards.

persons.name: Granbois
persons.context: Defendant in a cited appellate case (United States v. Granbois) referenced regarding legal standards.

persons.name: Marcus
persons.context: Defendant in a cited case (United States v. Marcus) referenced regarding the burden to justify limiting disclosure of witness identities.

persons.name: Marti
persons.context: Defendant in a cited Second Circuit case (United States v. Marti) referenced regarding defendants' interests in witness identifying information and the confrontation clause.

persons.name: Kelly
persons.context: Defendant in two cited cases (United States v. Kelly) referenced as examples where courts permitted the use of pseudonyms for alleged victims of sex abuse.

persons.name: Raniere
persons.context: Defendant in a cited case (United States v. Raniere) referenced regarding the chilling effect on witnesses and the fact that public availability of some names doesn't reveal all details.

persons.name: Graham
persons.context: Defendant in a cited case (United States v. Graham) referenced as an example where courts permitted the use of pseudonyms for alleged victims of sex trafficking.

persons.name: Gardner
persons.context: Defendant in a cited case (United States v. Gardner) referenced as an example where courts permitted the use of pseudonyms for alleged victims of sex abuse.

persons.name: Martinez
persons.context: Defendant in a cited case (Martinez) referenced regarding the deterrence of victims from coming forward.

connections.description: The document references public statements made by alleged victims relating to both Ms. Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein, implying their association in the alleged criminal activity.
The judge cites the legal precedent set in United States v. Dupigny to support rulings on procedural matters in Maxwell's case.

events.title: Hearing in United States v. Dupigny
events.description: A transcript from a hearing in the Dupigny case is cited by the judge regarding the use of the term 'victim' and jury instructions.

events.title: Government Motion on Pseudonyms Granted
events.description: The judge grants the government's motion to allow eight individuals (alleged victims and some witnesses) to be referred to by pseudonyms or first names during the trial to protect their privacy and prevent harassment.

events.title: Deadline for Joint Proposals
events.description: The judge orders the parties to submit joint proposals by November 10 regarding the nomenclature for pseudonyms, a limiting instruction for the jury, and logistics for voir dire related to witness anonymity.

keyFacts: The judge rules it is appropriate for the government to use the term 'victim' during trial, as it represents the government's litigating position, and any potential prejudice will be addressed through jury instructions.

The judge grants the government's motion to allow eight individuals (alleged victims and certain witnesses) to be referred to by pseudonyms or first names in open court to protect them from media harassment, embarrassment, and to encourage other victims to come forward.
The defense is already aware of the true identities of all these individuals, and the jury will also be made aware; the pseudonyms are only for public court proceedings.

The judge finds the defense's arguments against pseudonyms unpersuasive, noting that the need to protect witnesses from third-party harassment and the sensitive nature of the testimony are sufficient justifications.

The judge outlines a process for the parties to agree on pseudonyms and related jury instructions by a November 10 deadline, and maintains that the defense's right to cross-examine witnesses on credibility will not be unduly limited by the use of pseudonyms.
